title: Literacy in the Digital University
abstractText:
These seminars bring together researchers and practitioners from different disciplinary backgrounds to discuss digital communication in post-school education. The aims are to understand the changing meaning of literacy in this context, to evaluate practices around the notion of digital literacy, and to form a research network to stimulate further research in this highly significant area of educational development.

The seminars are being led  and hosted by a core group of researchers involved in four projects at different institutions that approach issues of literacy, learning and technology from different perspectives. They address four main themes:

  • The relation of new media practices to traditional literacy practice in the academy and the professions
  •  Digital texts and practices in formal and informal contexts and the transfer of learning across boundaries
  • Methodologies for research in literacy and learning in digital contexts
  • A  Research Agenda for Literacy in the Digital University.

The series maintains a website (http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/lidu/index.shtml) with the proceedings of all the seminars, and a blog (http://literacyinthedigitaluniversity.blogspot.com/) for parallel ongoing comment. The main outcome will be an edited volume of papers authored by the core group and others who have contributed to the discussions.

findingsText: This project was a research seminar series. We have developed a better understanding of the relation between university literacy practices and new digital communication practices. This has informed further research in 'digital literacies' funded by JISC and also the development of a new research network for the Society for Research in Higher Education, and a Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship project. Developing further research around the digital university through the SRHE Digital University network Education
